A second reason it is hard to choose essentials is social awkwardness. 

We are wired to want to get along with others. 

Thousands of years ago, our survival depended on it. 

Conforming to group expectations is no longer a matter of life and death. 

However, the desire to conform is still ingrained in us. 

This is why we feel discomfort when saying no. 

An old friend invites us to dinner. 

A boss asks us to take on a project. 

A neighbor begs us to help with the bake sale. 

The thought of saying no brings physical discomfort. 

We feel guilty. 

We don’t want to let someone down. 

We worry about damaging the relationship. 

These emotions muddle our clarity. 

They distract us from reality. 

We can say no and regret it briefly. 

Or we can say yes and regret it for much longer. 

The only way out is to learn to say no. 

We must say no firmly, resolutely, and gracefully. 

Once we do, our fears are often exaggerated. 

People actually respect us more. 

Since becoming an Essentialist, I see this is true. 

People admire those who have the courage to say no. 

Peter Drucker was a master of the graceful no. 

Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi wanted to interview creative individuals. 

Drucker’s response was interesting enough to quote verbatim. 

He expressed admiration for Mihaly and his work. 

But he said he had to disappoint him. 

He could not possibly answer Mihaly’s questions. 

He mentioned being told he was creative. 

He did not know what that meant. 

He just kept plodding along. 

He hoped Mihaly would not think him presumptuous or rude. 

He stated one of the secrets of productivity is...

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Our innate fear of social awkwardness often prevents us from saying no to nonessential requests, but learning to do so can lead to greater respect and clarity in our lives.
